results.title: Vintage: A History of Wine. Eps. 9 & 10
results.creator_credit: Malone Gill Productions, WGBH (Boston), Channel 4, Michael Gill and Christopher Ralling
results.brief_description: The power of the purse recounts the rise of Bordeaux as the prime wine producing area of France in the eighteenth century. Massive investment by the nouveaux riches led to the rise of Chateaux Latour, Lafite and Margaux and others who based their success on well-drained soil and insistence on the latest and best cellar techniques. “The devastator” describes the catastrophic effect on the French wine industry of phylloxera which wiped out almost all of the vineyards. Scientific investigations by Pasteur and Planchon solved the problem and introduced new techniques to viticulture.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Malone Gill Productions, WGBH (Boston), Channel 4, Michael Gill and Christopher Ralling

results.title: Vintage: A History of Wine. Eps. 7 & 8
results.creator_credit: Malone Gill Productions, WGBH (Boston), Channel Four, Michael Gill and Christopher Ralling
results.brief_description: Sipping stars recounts the history of champagne, from its invention by Dom Perignon during the reign of Louis XIV, the addition of the bubbles by the British during the reign of Charles II and the introduction of mass production methods by La Veuve Clicquot which led to its international success. “Wine and war” shows how the sweet fortified wines, particularly Madeira and Port were embraced by the British and Americans when French and German wines became unobtainable during the Napoleonic wars.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Malone Gill Productions, WGBH (Boston), Channel Four, Michael Gill and Christopher Ralling

results.title: Vintage: A History of Wine. Eps. 5 & 6
results.creator_credit: Malone Gill Productions, WGBH (Boston), Channel 4, Michael Gill and Christopher Ralling
results.brief_description: Precious but perishable Due to poor storage in wooden barrels in the middle ages, wine tended to deteriorate quickly. This led to England, the major consumer of the time, importing claret from Bordeaux which was close, and the stronger, longer lasting, malmsey and sack (sherry) from the eastern Mediterranean and Spain. “The slopes of gold” looks at the rise of the great vineyards of Burgundy where each tiny vineyard produces individual wine whose qualities are determined by the geology of the area.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Malone Gill Productions, WGBH (Boston), Channel 4, Michael Gill and Christopher Ralling

results.title: Vintage: A History of Wine. Eps. 3 & 4
results.creator_credit: Malone Gill Productions, WGBH (Boston), Channel 4, Michael Gill and Christopher Ralling
results.brief_description: The empire of the vine tells how cultivation of the vine brought civilisation to the Mediterranean, through the Greeks and Romans who spread its cultivation from the area around Pompeii, to Tuscany and into France via the Rhone valley. “Northern limits” looks at the history of German vineyards along the Moselle and Rhine rivers. Initiated by the Romans at Trier, continued by Charlemagne and the Cistercian monks in the middle ages, experiments with new wines continue to this day in this apparently inhospitable climate.

results.title: Vintage: A History of Wine. Eps. 1 & 2
results.creator_credit: Malone Gill Productions, WGBH (Boston), Channel 4, Michael Gill and Christopher Ralling
results.brief_description: The first two episodes of a thirteen part survey by Hugh Johnson of the history of wine. “First pressing” looks at the origins of winemaking in the Caucusus mountains of Georgia and its enjoyment in ancient middle eastern cultures until the prohibition enforced by Islam. “Drinking the god” looks at the role wine has played in religious ceremonies from pagan sacrifices, Dionysian orgies and Jewish ritual to the Christian mass. The programs look at how Georgia and the Middle East use and produce wine today.

results.title: Vintage Dave Allen
results.brief_description: For lovers of this great Irish comedian, this is a feast of his most brilliant monologues and sketches which were shown in Dave Allen’s television program. Allen selected the sketches himself and they celebrate twenty years of his association with the British Broadcasting Corporation.

results.title: Vingt-quatre heures de la vie d'une femme = Twenty-four hours in a woman's life
results.brief_description:
Alice is a beautiful woman who lives in fear in ageing. During a holiday spent in an Italian casino town, she is seduced by Thomas, a much younger man with gambling debts and many secrets.

Credits: Director, Dominique Delouche ; writers, Marie-France Riviere, Dominique Delouche ; photography, Walter Wottitz ; music, Jean Prodromides.
Cast: Danielle Darrieux, Robert Hoffman, Marthe Alycia, Lena Skerla, Romina Power.

results.title: Vindhya Pradesh
results.creator_credit: Films Division, Government of India, M. Bhavnani and Mushir Ahmad
results.brief_description: The State of Vindhya Pradesh includes 26 of the 36 former principalities of Central India. This film deals with the development of the State and the people who depend on the diamond and limestone mines for their living. Also presents sidelights of its great historical past.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Films Division, Government of India, M. Bhavnani and Mushir Ahmad
